metadata.name: Curriculum Design
metadata.description: Principles and methods for designing educational programs, learning sequences, and instructional materials. Covers learning objectives, backward design, spiral curriculum, sequencing, content alignment, and interdisciplinary design.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: The systematic planning of educational programs, learning sequences, and instructional materials

positive_examples: The curriculum was designed with clear learning outcomes aligned to assessments.
We used backward design, starting with what students should know by the end.
The scope and sequence document maps skills across all grade levels.
Curriculum mapping ensures coherence from unit to unit.
negative_examples: The teacher gave a lecture on photosynthesis.
Students completed the worksheet in class.
The classroom had new desks arranged in rows.
training_hints.disambiguation: Planning and organizing educational programs, not teaching activities

candidates.definition: Clear, measurable statements of what learners should know, understand, or be able to do

positive_examples: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to identify three causes of the Civil War.
The learning objective uses an action verb that can be observed and measured.
Objectives should be SMART: specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, time-bound.
Students will demonstrate mastery by solving quadratic equations with 80% accuracy.
negative_examples: Students will understand photosynthesis.
Learners will appreciate literature.
The goal is for students to be better at math.
training_hints.disambiguation: Specific measurable outcomes, not vague aspirations

candidates.definition: Planning instruction by first identifying desired results, then determining evidence of learning, then designing learning experiences

positive_examples: Start with the end in mind: what do we want students to understand?
Design the assessment first, then build instruction that prepares students for it.
The three stages: identify desired results, determine acceptable evidence, plan learning experiences.
What would count as evidence that students truly understand, not just memorized?
negative_examples: Let's see what activities look fun and figure out what we're teaching later.
I'll cover the textbook chapter by chapter in order.
We'll write the test after we see what we managed to cover.
training_hints.disambiguation: Starting with outcomes, not with activities or content coverage

candidates.definition: Revisiting key concepts repeatedly at increasing levels of complexity and depth over time

positive_examples: Fractions are introduced in grade 2, revisited in grade 4 with operations, and again in grade 6 with algebra.
Each time we return to this concept, we go deeper and connect to more complex ideas.
The spiral ensures students encounter key ideas multiple times at increasing sophistication.
Building on prior knowledge while adding new layers of understanding.
negative_examples: We covered that topic in third grade, so we don't need to revisit it.
Each unit is completely separate from the others.
Once we finish a chapter, we move on and don't look back.
training_hints.disambiguation: Returning to topics with increasing depth, not one-and-done coverage

candidates.definition: Ordering learning experiences to build logically from simpler to more complex, ensuring prerequisites precede dependent skills

positive_examples: Students must master addition before we introduce multiplication.
The task analysis revealed five prerequisite skills that need to be taught first.
Learning progressions map how understanding develops from novice to expert.
Each step builds on the previous one in a logical sequence.
negative_examples: We'll cover topics in whatever order feels interesting.
Jump straight to the advanced technique without building up to it.
The curriculum follows the textbook order without analyzing dependencies.
training_hints.disambiguation: Logical ordering based on dependencies, not arbitrary sequencing

candidates.definition: Ensuring coherence between learning objectives, instructional activities, and assessments

positive_examples: The test measures exactly what the objectives state students should learn.
Activities provide practice on the skills that will be assessed.
There's a clear line from standards to objectives to activities to assessments.
What we teach, how we teach, and how we assess are all aligned.
negative_examples: The test included topics we never covered in class.
We did fun activities but they weren't connected to the learning goals.
The objectives mentioned analysis, but the test only asked for recall.
training_hints.disambiguation: Coherence between goals, teaching, and assessment

candidates.definition: Integrating content and skills from multiple subject areas around authentic themes or problems

positive_examples: The unit on climate change integrates science, math, geography, and persuasive writing.
Students use historical research methods to analyze primary sources while building literacy skills.
The project connects art, engineering, and physics through bridge design.
Real-world problems don't respect subject boundaries.
negative_examples: Math is from 9-10, then English from 10-11, completely separate.
Science class never mentions what students are learning in other subjects.
Each discipline is taught in isolation.
training_hints.disambiguation: Deliberate integration across subjects, not siloed disciplines
